channel.title: BUbreakingSectionTwo
channel.description: This is a randomly ordered feed of the most recent entries from BUbreakingSectionTwo, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: Netflix co-CEO Ted Sarandos credits a video store job for launching his career—and cherishes this lesson from Tony Bennett
item.description: "It was an MBA course and film school all wrapped up into one for me," he said.

item.title: MacKenzie Scott is trying to close the DEI gap in higher ed, with $155 million in donations this week alone
item.description: These gifts are a “major source of encouragement” during uncertain times for higher education.

item.title: On Pope Leo’s Visit to Lebanon and Turkey, A.I. Was a Frequent Concern
item.description: On his first trip as pontiff, Leo XIV predictably called for peace and unity. But he also addressed technology’s promise and pitfalls.

item.title: Netflix’s bombshell deal to buy Warner Bros. brings Batman and Harry Potter to the big red streamer and infuriates theater owners and the Ellisons
item.description: Just days before Netflix emerged as the highest bidder, Paramount tore into the "myopic process" that had become "tainted."

item.title: Netflix to Buy Warner Bros in $83 Billion Deal
item.description: The deal to acquire the Hollywood behemoth’s television and film studios as well as HBO Max will bulk up the world’s biggest paid streaming service.

item.title: Trump Administration Says Europe Faces ‘Civilizational Erasure’
item.description: America’s goal should be “to help Europe correct its current trajectory,” the administration said in its new National Security Strategy.

item.title: Elon Musk and Bill Gates warn that AI will kill all jobs within 20 years. ‘That’s not what we’re seeing,’ LinkedIn exec says
item.description: Elon Musk may predict a jobless future, but LinkedIn’s latest hiring data shows demand rising, not collapsing. That will be music to Gen Z's ears.

item.title: FIFA’s Leader Often Flatters Trump. Now, He’s Awarding a Peace Prize.
item.description: Gianni Infantino, head of soccer’s governing body, has been ingratiating himself with the president to help ensure a successful 2026 World Cup.

item.title: Apple is experiencing its biggest leadership shakeup since Steve Jobs died
item.description: The exodus of top talent spans critical divisions from AI to design, legal affairs, environmental policy, and operations.

item.title: An End to Hepatitis B Shots for All Newborns
item.description: A federal panel voted on Friday to recommend halting the at-birth shots for all infants, in a step toward Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s goa...

item.title: How Batteries Got Cheaper and Made the Electric Grid More Reliable
item.description: An early grid battery was installed in the Atacama Desert in Chile 15 years ago. Now, as prices have tumbled, they are increasingly being used around ...

item.title: On Pope Leo’s Visit to Lebanon and Turkey, A.I. Was a Frequent Concern
item.description: On his first trip as pontiff, Leo XIV predictably called for peace and unity. But he also addressed technology’s promise and pitfalls.

item.title: Putin Basks in Praise From Modi on India Visit
item.description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi lauded President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, underlining the close personal relationship between the leaders and their c...

item.title: FIFA’s Leader Often Flatters Trump. Now, He’s Awarding a Peace Prize.
item.description: Gianni Infantino, head of soccer’s governing body, has been ingratiating himself with the president to help ensure a successful 2026 World Cup.

item.description: America’s goal should be “to help Europe correct its current trajectory,” the administration said in its new National Security Strategy.
